m:properties.d:SessionName: Learn Like Your Life Depends On It
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
You have read this far, great! I already know this session is for you. How do I know? It is exceedingly rare that today’s “9-5” job provides anywhere near what is needed to develop the career you want to have. For the purposes of this session it does not matter if you are a newly minted, “wet behind the ears” data professional or a grizzled veteran. What does matter is that you know that you have a career oriented mindset and a desire to grow beyond what you are today.
This session is designed to help with just that. In addition to talking about a learning plan that fits your needs, we will discuss how to execute that plan, including lab environments, as well as resources to help you execute those plans. If you have reached this point, you simply need to be in this session, see you there.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Understanding Indexes for Writing Better Queries
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
As a developer, analyst, or beginner, it's relatively easy to learn how to query a database for information. T-SQL is a declarative language, meaning we simply tell the engine what to get, not how to get it. Some queries are fast, others are slow. We've all heard that an index will make the query faster, and often the solution to performance problems are indeed indexes. Why is that? What are they? How do you use them? With a good understanding of what indexes are and how the engine uses them, and by writing our queries with indexes in mind, we can make queries perform much faster.
In this beginner session we'll learn index basics and how to write queries that can take advantage of them for more efficient, better-performing queries.

m:properties.d:SessionName: From Development to Production: Using Containers for Your Database
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
In this talk, you will learn how to leverage Docker and Kubernetes to deploy SQL Server consistently in a variety of environments, including on your computer and in Azure. The skills you learn can also be applied to other databases that can be containerized, such as PostgreSQL.
You will leave with an understanding of when this deployment model is appropriate and when you might want to consider another option. You will also gain an understanding of how this approach will change your DevOps pipeline.

m:properties.d:SessionName: ...NUMA?
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Non-uniform memory access (NUMA) architectures are complex, yet important for understanding large systems. From physical NUMA to vNUMA and soft-NUMA, there are considerations at different layers of the stack that can all have a significant impact on performance and scalability.
In this session, we'll focus on what you need to know about NUMA to realize high performance in a common stack: SQL Server on Windows on VMware on Intel. We will start by discussing what NUMA is at the hardware layer and the opportunities that it presents. We will then move on to how BIOS and VM settings can change the presentation, and finally how SQL Server uses its "NUMA-awareness" to increase performance and scalability.
By the end of this session, you'll be able to explain what NUMA is, describe how it can affect workloads, and configure your infrastructure for high performance.

m:properties.d:SessionName: An Introduction to Azure Data Studio
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: This session will provide a high level overview of Azure Data Studio and highlight some of the differences from SQL Server Management Studio. We cover saved connections, how to get both the actual and estimated Execution plans, workspaces and one of my favorite features, Notebooks. We also go over what an extension is and why I would want to use them.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Using SQL Server tools to Find Performance Bottlenecks
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Abstract: Performance is always at the top of every DBA’s list of things to do. There are many tools that are available that are native to SQL Server. This session will cover how to use Extended Events, DMVs, Execution Plans and QueryStore to find performance bottlenecks.
Topics to be covered, as well as a few surprises • Query Timeouts • Index Fragmentation • Execution Plan Warnings • Missing Indexes • SQL Server Wait information • Missing Statistics • Query bottlenecks • Data type conversion issues • CPU and Memory Issues • IO issues • Deadlocks
This session will also cover a few additional topics such as how to format your SQL code allowing for easier reading. How to perform a complete server assessment and baseline will also be covered as part of the session.
REGISTER HERE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/precons-sqlsaturday-sioux-falls-tickets-63432355884

m:properties.d:SessionName: Become a T-SQL Pivoting Ninja in 59.9 Minutes Or Less
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Would you like to create Pivot Tables in SQL with ease?
Become a query writing ninja who uses the Pivot operator to move unique column values into multiple column names for better data insight. In this demo-heavy presentation, you will learn how to create pivot tables enhanced with multiple aggregate columns and column totals using Rollup and Cube operators, and the grouping function. Attendees will also learn to use the Unpivot Operator.
Come join me, and by the end of this session, you will have the knowledge to level up your pivoting skills to that of a ninja or maybe even *Chuck Norris. *Not Possible

m:properties.d:SessionName: Data Hub Automation with Databricks Delta
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Databricks Delta is the new standard for building a data lake as a part to your data warehouse. In this sessions we will learn how we can automate the development and ETL of a Data Hub\PSE in Databricks Delta that can process 1000's of tables with minimal code.
Agenda: - Data Lake Design and the Modern Data Warehouse - Databricks Delta - Automating Databricks Delta

m:properties.d:SessionName: Free Your Data! A Deep Dive into Power BI Dataflows
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Power BI dataflows bring Self-Service Data Prep to a whole new level. We'll look at how you can "Free Your Data!" and get data to your users faster, all within the Power BI Platform. In this session, we will discuss:
1. What are Power BI dataflows? 2. How can I use Power BI dataflows effectively across my organization?

m:properties.d:SessionName: Query Plans For Visual Learners
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: You’ve looked at query plans and done some tuning, but you’re not sure what’s going on underneath. Hash Match? Merge Join? Watch both come to life in animations, and more! See (not just hear) the inner workings of a plan, and learn about the details that matter for performance. When plans make sense, tuning will become easier, and maybe even fun!

m:properties.d:SessionName: Intro to Query Store
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
In this session, we will look at the new Query Store feature in SQL Server 2016, 2017, and 2019. Query Store tracks changes in execution plans, allowing you to easily view performance differences and revert to older plans with a few clicks of the mouse in 2016.
Then in 2017, Microsoft added wait stats per query plan and Automatic Plan Correction capabilities. Allowing DBAs more tools to troubleshoot fires with and a way to automatically resolve issues.
In this session, we will walk through the features of the Query Store, so you can understand how to use them in SQL Server 2016, 2017, and 2019.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Power BI Governance from A-Z
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: A successful Power BI deployment requires careful consideration in a number of different areas. Missing one or multiple areas in your deployment can have negative short or long-term consequences in your organization. Learn how to implement a Power BI architecture that will scale as the self-service analytics culture grows in your organization. After this session, attendees should come away confident knowing all the requirements for a sustainable and scalable Power BI deployment.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Beyond the Proverbial Box - Customizing the Power BI Experience (Pre-Con)
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Power BI provides numerous features allowing us to customize the Power BI user experience. This day-long, hands-on workshop explores these features by working through the implementation of a Power BI Solution. This session implements features including: - Highly interactive report pages leveraging bookmarks, buttons, drillthrough, and custom tooltips - Templates and themes - Filter pane customization - Using custom visualizations and slicers - Table of contents and menuing - DAX and role-playing dimensions - Custom shape maps - Row-level security Learn how to create Power BI user experiences that go beyond the “out-of-the-box” functionality and finish the day with a working example of these customizations.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Building data driven Azure Data Factory pipelines
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Have you ever worked in ETL environments that have hundreds of connections, datasets, and packages to drive repetitive loads? In this session we'll walk-through how to build metadata pipelines in Azure Data Factory and show patterns how you can copy hundreds of files or tables with just a few objects in ADF. Recommended to have some experience with ETL (SSIS, ADF, Other).

m:properties.d:SessionName: Difficult Queries
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Take your T-SQL skills to the next level. Regardless of your current level there will be something here you'll be glad you didn't miss. Basics like avoiding cursors in iterative tasks and multi-database executions are the tip of the iceberg. If queries are basic arithmetic then this is basic algebra. First we see how coding style affects maintainability then dive into several types of encapsulation, parameterization and tricks with values, cross apply, pivot and more .

m:properties.d:SessionName: Designing the Modern Enterprise Data Warehouse in Azure
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
With the smorgasbord of Azure service available, how do you approaching building a modern enterprise data warehouse?
In this pre-con we will be covering both architecture patterns from Microsoft and in the industry on how to move to Azure for you data warehousing needs. We'll cover the various offerings of Azure including storage, data ingestion and orchestration, databases , NoSQL, Azure Synapse, and streaming.
We'll also cover how to analyze all of this data with tools and services like Power BI and Databricks. Finally, we'll cover strategies on how you get there; Lift-and-shift, hybrid, or brand new implementations will all be discussed.
By the end of this pre-con you should have a thorough understanding of the architecting a modern enterprise data warehouse in Azure including getting those services to work together and how to use that data effectively!

m:properties.d:SessionName: AI, Machine Learning and Deep Learning in Azure
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Artificial intelligence is more a part of our lives than we realize. This session will go in-depth on AI, explaining how and when machine learning and its counterpart deep learning are used to create Artificial Intelligence. Using Azure Cognitive Services and other tools within Azure, users are now able to put these technologies to work for their organizations. Attendees will learn clear definitions of each of these technologies, how each can be applied, and how they are already being used in different areas of businesses around the world. In addition, this session will provide examples showing how and where each can be used in Azure.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Git: Simplifying the Complexity
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Git's version control offers powerful ways to manage your revision history, allows extreme control of change history, and is great for distributed teams of any size. It's why many organizations are choosing to use git as their version control system. But, the complexity can make it difficult to use. In this session, we take a database developer's view of the powerful distributed version control system and simplify the workflow to help reduce the complexity for your team.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Collaborative Tabular Development
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Analysis Services tabular models are represented by a single .bim file. This can make it difficult to collaborate on model development as a team. Using Tabular Editor, we'll demonstrate how you can effectively divide and conquer your model development as a team. We'll also show how this approach can be incorporated into a continuous integration (CI) / continuous deployment (CD) solution using DevOps pipelines to further support development best practices.

m:properties.d:SessionName: SubQueries, Common Table Expressions, and Temp Tables
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: This session will go over best practices for using subqueries, common table expressions (CTEs), and Temp Tables. We'll review basic concepts and then several examples. The focus will be on building efficient queries to solve complex problems while remaining understandable. Participants should feel welcome to bring their own complex query problems that we can work through together.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Pandas, Koalas, and Spark(s) Oh my! An introduction to Dataframes and their place in Databricks
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Dataframes are at the front and center of Data Science and analytics, and when working in Databricks, the choices for which dataframe to use can be daunting. This session will cover the different languages and their dataframes, the pros and cons to each, and where they fit in when working within the Databricks ecosystem.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Trillion Row Tables
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Ever wonder what loading and querying a trillion rows into a single table looks like in SQL Server? I will walk you through what happens when you blow up the FizzBuzz problem to the trillion row scale. You're going to learn all sorts of cool stuff about columnstore, like how compression works, tips and tricks for huge data loads, and best practices for querying very large columnstore tables.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Using dynamic SQL effectively
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Dynamic SQL is a powerful tool that many applications use. Many of us are aware of the dangers of dynamic SQL, particularly SQL injection and plan cache bloat. Dynamic SQL is also inherently harder to troubleshoot than native SQL for functional and performance problems.
In this session, we will discuss how to use dynamic SQL effectively and correctly to avoid these and other dangers. We will discuss parameterized dynamic SQL, input validation and sanitation, and how to write your code so that it does not hinder troubleshooting. We will discuss suggestions that those who support application code can pass on to their development teams to incorporate into existing code.
Attendees will leave with the confidence and knowledge they need to develop and support application code that uses dynamic SQL effectively.

m:properties.d:SessionName: MLflow: Machine Learning Best Practices in Action
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: MLflow is an incredible open-source tool that offers excellent solutions to tracking each iteration of machine learning application, comparing each run, then packaging up the top-performing model and implementing the model. This tool reinforces model development best practices and provides excellent, easily implemented support. In this tutorial, we will review model development best practices, then spend time implementing MLflow with hands-on practice of the open-source tools.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Using the BEAM* Framework to Design an Agile Data Warehouse
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: The BEAM* framework of provides for an agile approach to data warehouse design. By incorporating better and more engaged communications between designers, BI/DW development team and all stakeholders the BEAM* method speeds up the normally extended development lifecycle by providing more value in an iterative approach. The outline of this methodology will be discussed along with the use of the BEAM* diagrams and how they aid in all stakeholders thinking in a dimensional manner.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Introduction to Indexing 101
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: This session is for the absolute beginner and will begin with a focus on how data is stored in data pages and the data structures of a Heap and a Clustered Index. We will see how to read table operators in an Execution Plan. Then we will move on to creating Non-Clustered Indexes, how an index can cover a query, and how to include a column in an Index. John has been a Microsoft Certified Trainer (MCT) for over 20 years, a former Microsoft MVP, and is currently a SQL Premier Field Engineer for Microsoft.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Performance Improvements in SQL Server 2019
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Microsoft released SQL Server 2019 in November. The latest version contains several improvements and new features that improve reliability and performance. First, Accelerated Database Recovery (ADR) completely redesigns the SQL Server database engine recovery process. This allows the time spent recovering from a crash or rolling back a transaction to be greatly reduced. ADR also prevents the transaction log from growing during a long-running transaction. Second, metadata for temporary tables can be stored in in-memory tables. For tempdb-heavy workloads, this removes a bottleneck and provides an improvement to performance. Finally, SQL Server 2019 supports the use of persistent-memory (PMEM) devices. PMEM can be used to persist the transaction log buffer, effectively removing LOGWRITE waits. Join me for this session to learn about these new features in SQL Server 2019 and how they can make your workload run faster.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Ethics, Morals, and Laws for the DBA 101
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Ethics, Morals, and Laws each govern one aspect of our behavior as people and DBAs. They govern which actions we take and which actions we avoid.
Understanding the basics of these guides and how they coordinate (and sometimes conflict) with each other helps you to make choices you can live with from both a personal and professional perspective.
This session presents basic definitions, ideas, and discussion points. It is intended to be an interactive presentation where the audience contributes to the discussion, so no two presentations are exactly the same!

m:properties.d:SessionName: Using Space to Tell Your Story
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: You can be the best technician in the world, but if you can't explain what it is you do to others, your career will stall. In this session we'll talk about ways to share your knowledge with others, both via the web but especially in presentation form. We'll talk about the content you're delivering, and how it has an arc just like any novel. The room is your stage, and how you relate to the people you present to will make or break your message. We'll also talk about movement, eye contact, dealing with unfriendly audiences, and more.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Beginning Admin: The Care and Feeding of SQL Server
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Design and development may be exciting, but database administration is absolutely critical (and, reasonably well-paying!) The care and feeding of a server tends to get short-changed or neglected. In this class, we'll cover the basics of the big five administrator tasks:
* Backups – You must set up regular backups, to keep copies of your databases...just in case something breaks, or someone makes a bad, bad mistake. * Integrity checks – Regularly and automatically check databases for corruption, which is when bits get scrambled, lost, and ruined. * Index maintenance – Databases need regular upkeep so they'll continue to run well. * Disk management – It's actually your job to find out about full disks before they happen. After all, databases grow! * Alerting – Alerts tell you what's wrong, so you don't have to go looking for problems.
Being a database administrator is a big job, but we can cover the basics in one session!

m:properties.d:SessionName: The Master Stored Procedure Workshop: Part 1
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Your job includes designing and writing stored procedures, but you haven’t had a lot of actual training on the subject, right? I will show you how to write stored procedures from scratch, using the design advice I’ve accumulated in my 20+ years of experience. Here are a few of the things you’ll learn: When and how to use stored procedures The benefits and basics of contractual programming How to write stored procedures from scratch How to structure and organize stored procedures Key techniques for ideal stored procedure management Troubleshooting and debugging stored procedures The session will be packed with tons of code examples, with plenty of labs to reinforce key concepts. Beginner and experienced T-SQL programmers both will walk away with a greater understanding of how to design, manage, and troubleshoot stored procedures. Join mefor one fun session of SQL Server programming!

m:properties.d:SessionName: Cosmos DB Develop Locally Deploy Globally
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
CosmosDB is Microsoft’s globally distributed, massively scalable, cloud based database that is hosted in AZURE. Who cares? You should if you need to support thousands of transactions a second, global distribution and redundancy, and different consistencies.
Do you need to support JSON, Graph, et al? Done. Join me and see how easy it is to get started. We will set up a local instance of CosmosDB, load JSON data, and build a PowerBI visualization. Along the way I’ll point out a couple of things to watch out for. At the end of the session, you will then learn how, with a couple of commands, to switch your visualization to the cloud.

m:properties.d:SessionName: SQL Server 2019 - New Features and Enhancements
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: SQL Server 2019 was released in November 2019. It is time now to learn about some awesome features of this release. Like previous versions, SQL Server 2019 comes with a plethora of new features as well as with enhancements to the existing features. In this session, I will discuss and show demos about new features such as Accelerated Database Recovery, Intelligent Query Processing, In-memory Optimized Tempdb metadata and much more. This is an introductory session to introduce you to these new features. One hour will not be enough time to go in depth in any one feature. You will leave this session with a solid understanding of some of the best new features of SQL Server 2019 which will help you and your company make decisions such as when and why to upgrade your database platform.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Building Reactive Dashboards with R and SQL Server
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
R can do more than just statistics and data viz! In this session I will demonstrate the packages and techniques for building reactive web dashboards with R and SQL Server.
This session will cover: * An introduction to the Shiny package and reactive concepts * R database integration * Load Testing * Caching Strategies

m:properties.d:SessionName: Automatic Inlining of Scalar UDFs into SQL Queries in SQL Server 2019
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: In SQL Server 2019, a new feature called Scalar UDF (User Defined Function) inlining was introduced as a part of Intelligent Query Processing. Scalar UDFs in SQL Server typically end up performing poorly due to the following reasons - Iterative invocation, Lack of costing, Interpreted execution, and Serial execution. However, the new feature significantly improves the performance of scalar UDFs by automatically translating entire UDFs into SQL queries. In this talk, we will demonstrate the several benefits of this new feature including an experimental evaluation that shows performance improvements of up to multiple orders of magnitude on real workloads.

m:properties.d:SessionName: SQL Server Storage IO: Strategic and Operational Insight
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: The first part of this session will walk through the Windows OS, Hypervisor, and host server constructs comprising SQL Server storage. We'll discuss how the various types of SQL Server disk IO can inform storage planning. Next, a structured look at SQL Server disk IO observability provided by perfmon and the SQL Server DMVs will be presented. Enterprise monitoring tools build on the insight provided by perfmon and the DMVs, so no-one will be left out! A storage profile can be built from SQL Server workload observation, allowing for planning based on the profile. A load testing tool like diskspd can be used to verify performance targets at a load based on the profile. The final part of the session will explore the daily operational insight that perfmon and the DMVs can provide as SQL Server continues to be monitored.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Six Ways to Improve SQL Server Application Security
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
You know that vulnerabilities exist in your code, in your database. And you want to do something about it. That's good - you're on the leading edge. But what? Where do you start?
In this session, we'll talk about six mindsets you should adopt as you move toward a more secure database development environment. While the strategies are broad, we'll delve into each with specific tactics and examples. By the end of the session, you'll have actionable ideas on how you can move security and privacy forward in your company.
m:properties.d:SessionPrerequisites: An understanding of SQL Server security features would be helpful.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Data Science 101 for Analysts
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Data Scientists rely heavily upon a broad team of data engineers, data analysts, and business analysts. However, data science is not always transparent around methodology and process. Data science is an excellent platform to solve problems and should not be a black box mystery. The more knowledge is shared the better the team and project will become!
This session will give an overview of the following topics: - Types of problems that data science can solve - Types of organizational frameworks - Data scientist skill sets - The machine learning modeling life cycle - A walk through the modeling life cycle in action - A framework to assess a machine learning model

m:properties.d:SessionName: Azure Synapse Analytics
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Azure Synapse is a limitless analytics service that brings together enterprise data warehousing and Big Data analytics using either serverless on-demand or provisioned resources—at scale. In this session you will learn how Azure Synapse brings these two worlds together with a unified experience to ingest, prepare, manage, and serve data for immediate BI and machine learning needs.

m:properties.d:SessionName: TBD - Women In Technology AM
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: more details to come on some exciting speakers we have lined up for the morning WIT session.

m:properties.d:SessionName: TBD - Women In Technology PM
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: more details to come on some exciting speakers we have lined up for the afternoon WIT session.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Database Privacy and Security for Developers
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Oh, look... another data breach. And another. And another. Hardly a day goes by without a mention of one in the media. Thousands were reported last year, and thousands more didn't make the news. Size, industry, location - none of these are a determining factor anymore. We're all at risk, from malicious actors, insiders, even accidents. And more and more, the weaknesses that are being exploited are found not in the operating system, or the browser, or the network, but in the applications we create and manage.
So, developers... what are you going to do about it?
In this one-day session, we're going to discuss a range of topics that developers need to know in order to improve their applications' data security and privacy. We'll cover SQL injection, one of the most common exploits over the last twenty years, in-depth, along with other common vulnerabilities. We'll talk about how to apply permissions and encryption properly in SQL Server to directly protect your data. We'll see how th

m:properties.d:SessionName: Managing SQL Server on Windows Server Core
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Lately it seems more sysadmins are embracing Windows Server Core as the OS of choice for virtualized servers. SQL Server is (almost) perfectly happy to run in this environment but how do you manage on an OS without a full desktop.
We'll cover what versions and features are supported, how to install sql server via a configuration file, and what common activities are changed when you move into a Core environment.

m:properties.d:SessionName: SQL Server Policies - Underused Method for Configuring Your Database Server and Enforcing Standards
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: As a DBA for a financial clearing house and we are audited by multiple government regulators to make sure our database instances are configured to standards. When configuring an instance we have a checklist of configurations which must adhere to those standards. Then those configurations must be monitored to make sure they remain set according to those standards. This is time consuming, and labor intensive. If only there was a quick way to template those standards so that they could easily be applied and enforced to database instances. Well one way that can be done with SQL Server Policies !! SQL Server Policies can be used to both configure and enforce standards within a database instance. SQL Server Policies have been around since SQL Server 2008 , but have not gained much traction in the industry. SQL Server Policies been the "Rodney Dangerfield" of SQL Server features getting no respect. I'll show you how I used this feature to configure and enforce standards.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Power BI Sharing and Security
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Demo based and interactive presentation about sharing and securing Power BI datasets, reports and dashboards, will also cover Row Level Security.

m:properties.d:SessionName: HELP! HELP! My System Databases Are Gone!
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Your worst nightmare has happened. You had a server crash and lost your system databases. Now what? Watch me break SQL Server and then fix it again. This presentation will walk through regenerating and restoring your system databases to get back up and running. I will also discuss several situations I have faced and scenarios prepped for and strategies for preparing for the worst case DR situations.
